awd_titl_txt: RUI: Transcription Factor Discovery in the Extremophile Thermus Thermophilus
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences: Biological Sciences Directorate is funding Dr. Michael Van Dyke from Kennesaw State University to identify orphan transcription factors and their potential biological roles. Transcription factors are the primary regulators of gene expression in most organisms, controlling those genes that are turned on or off in response to intrinsic factors or external cues. Presently, the targets of most transcription factors are not known. However, using a novel selection method that allows the screening of trillions of DNA sequences, it is now possible to go from putative transcription factor to understanding its biological regulatory roles in relatively short order. This project will explore potential transcription factors in Thermus thermophilus, a model extremophile organism whose proteins are widely used in many aspects of biotechnology. Knowledge derived from this project will be applicable to a host of industries, ranging from agribusiness to waste treatment. In addition, this project will train a mix of undergraduate and graduate (MS) students in the biochemistry of protein-DNA interactions as well as bioinformatics and regulon development, thereby providing future scientists in these fields.  

This research project will be undertaken to better understand transcriptional regulatory networks in the model extremophile T. thermophilus HB8. Binding specificity of putative transcription factors will be determined by the combinatorial approach Restriction Endonuclease Protection, Selection, and Amplification, followed by massively parallel semiconductor sequencing and Multiple Expectation Maximization for Motif Elicitation analysis. Potential binding sites will then be mapped to the Thermus thermophilus HB8 genome using Find Individual Motif Occurrences and functionally validated both in vitro (electrophoretic mobility shift assays) and in vivo (quantitative Polymerase Chain Reactions). Information from this study will provide a better understanding of regulons within a model eubacterial extremophile and will complement ongoing studies, for example, the Structural-Biological Whole Cell Project, which seeks to understand the molecular constituents of life at an atomic level. Methods developed by this project should also be generally applicable to characterizing orphan transcription factors and eliciting regulons in other organisms.

por.por_cntn:
Kennesaw State University received an award to support investigations into orphan transcription factors in the extreme thermophilic organism, Thermus thermophilus HB8. Transcription factors are the primary regulators of gene expression in most organisms, controlling those genes that are turned on or off in response to intrinsic factors or external cues. Presently, the targets of most transcription factors are not known. However, using a novel selection method that allows the screening of trillions of DNA sequences, it is now possible to go from a putative transcription factor to understanding its biological regulatory roles in relatively short order. T. thermophilus HB8 is a model extremophile whose proteins are widely used in many aspects of biotechnology. Knowledge gained from these studies will increase our understanding of how life exists under extreme conditions and provide practical benefits in a host of industries, ranging from agribusiness to waste treatment.

 

Using a unique iterative selection method, Restriction Endonuclease Protection, Selection and Amplification (REPSA), massively parallel semiconductor sequencing, and MEME motif discovery, we determined DNA-binding consensus sequences for the TetR family proteins TTHA0101, TTHA0973, and TTHB023 and the CRP family proteins TTHB099 and TTHA1359. These were validated by independent biophysical assays, including electrophoretic mobility shift assays and biolayer interferometry, using a series of point mutations. Armed with this information, we performed a series of bioinformatic analyses to identify potential T. thermophilus HB8 genes regulated by these proteins. These were validated both in vitro (EMSA and BLI) and in vivo (microarray gene expression data, if publicly available). Taken together, these studies provided us with a better understanding of the biological roles of these transcriptional regulators in a model eubacterial organism. They also complemented ongoing studies, e.g., RIKEN's Structural-Biological Whole-Cell Project, which seeks to understand all biological processes at an atomic level.

 

Research performed for this project has been part of the education of thirteen undergraduate and five graduate students at Kennesaw State University. Notably, thirteen were female, three were international, and eight were minorities underrepresented in the sciences. These students gained knowledge in the properties of transcriptional regulatory proteins and modern methods for their analysis through their participation. Several have presented their research in either local or regional symposia, and some were co-authors on the five peer-reviewed publications that resulted from this research. Of those who have graduated, nine have gone on to graduate studies or found employment in STEM careers.

 

This project has led to developing a modular curriculum in our undergraduate research courses CHEM 2050 Introduction to Directed Research and CHEM 4100 Directed Applied Research. These courses provide both hands-on experience in advanced biochemistry/molecular biology techniques and instrumentation and exposure to the mindset of hypothesis-based research. Through this, students learn critical data analysis and problem-solving skills. They also have an opportunity to practice their oral and written communication skills in scientific venues. These courses will be essential parts of the training of future students, and ultimately, STEM researchers throughout the United States and beyond.

 

As part of our research, we have developed many techniques for studying proteins and nucleic acids specifically designed to be suitable for investigation by undergraduate researchers (i.e., safe, simple, low-cost). Several of these have been published at Protocols.io and are highly viewed by the scientific community (see https://www.protocols.io/researchers/michael-van-dyke/publications). We anticipate these will have a significant future impact on several aspects of biochemistry and molecular biology education and research, especially if they are undertaken in a primarily undergraduate environment.
